But mitigating the adverse effects of air pollution is as complex as the chemistry that produces these agents. For instance, one common air pollutant, sulfur dioxide (SO 2), complicates efforts to simultaneously control both global warming and air quality. Power plants, vehicles, and other sources emit SO 2 that forms sulfate particles, which harm human health but also effectively block solar radiation from reaching the surfaceâ€”a cooling effect.
20 China is seeking to reduce its SO 2 emissions in hopes of improving urban air quality.
21 But large reductions in SO 2 emissions could result in enhanced global warming, Melamed says.
